title: Clann Éireann
text:
Clann Éireann (; ), also known as the People's Party, was a minor <a href="Irish%20republicanism">republican</a> political party in the <a href="Irish%20Free%20State">Irish Free State</a>. The party was founded on 25 January 1926 as a result of a split from the ruling <a href="Cumann%20na%20nGaedheal">Cumann na nGaedheal</a> party, to protest against the <a href="Irish%20Boundary%20Commission">Boundary Commission</a> report, which permanently demarcated the border between the Free State and <a href="Northern%20Ireland">Northern Ireland</a>. Clann Éireann was the leading representative of constitutional republicanism in <a href="D%C3%A1il%20%C3%89ireann">Dáil Éireann</a> until the success of <a href="Fianna%20F%C3%A1il">Fianna Fáil</a> at the <a href="June%201927%20Irish%20general%20election">June 1927 general election</a>.
The party chairman was Professor <a href="William%20Magennis">William Magennis</a>, <a href="Teachta%20D%C3%A1la">Teachta Dála</a> (TD) for <a href="National%20University%20of%20Ireland%20%28constituency%29">National University of Ireland</a>. The secretaries included <a href="P%C3%A1draic%20%C3%93%20M%C3%A1ille">Pádraic Ó Máille</a> TD for Galway. Other prominent members of the party included <a href="Maurice%20George%20Moore">Maurice George Moore</a>, who at the time was a member of the <a href="Seanad%20%C3%89ireann%20%28Irish%20Free%20State%29">senate</a>, and <a href="Christopher%20Byrne%20%28politician%29">Christopher Byrne</a>, who was a sitting TD for Wicklow who was one of those who had resigned from Cumann na nGaedheal over the Boundary issue.
The party demanded for Ireland "one and indivisible as of right the full status of a sovereign State. We aim at restoring the unity of her territory and the union of all her people under one central supreme government". The party advocated the abolition of the <a href="Oath%20of%20Allegiance%20%28Ireland%29">Oath of Allegiance</a> to the <a href="Monarchy%20in%20the%20Irish%20Free%20State">British King</a>. It also called for lower taxes and less legislation. In policies like trade <a href="protectionism">protectionism</a> and the abolition of the Oath of Allegiance, it agreed with the agenda of <a href="Sinn%20F%C3%A9in">Sinn Féin</a> leader <a href="%C3%89amon%20de%20Valera">Éamon de Valera</a>. An attempt to lure de Valera and his followers into the party failed. After de Valera created the Fianna Fáil party in March 1926, Clann Éireann grew closer to that group.
The party attracted little support and it failed to win any seats in <a href="D%C3%A1il%20%C3%89ireann">Dáil Éireann</a> at the <a href="June%201927%20Irish%20general%20election">June 1927 general election</a>. Its seven candidates only attracted a few thousand first preference votes. Seven of them were last in their constituencies and forfeited their deposits. On 28 August 1927, the party issued a statement supporting Fianna Fáil, and ceased political activity.
